NPCSC deliberated on the CE's report and promulgated its decision on 26.4.04 (the NPCSC Decision). The NPCSC Decision is summarized as follows -
• the election of the third term CE in 2007 and LegCo in the fourth term in 2008 should not be by means of universal suffrage;
• the 50/50 ratio for Members returned by functional and geographical constituencies would remain unchanged for the fourth term LegCo;
• the procedures for voting on bills and motions in LegCo should remain unchanged; and
• subject to the above not being contravened, the "electoral methods" could be appropriately amended, consistent with the principle of gradual and orderly progress and in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Basic Law.

The House Committee agreed to form a Bills Committee to study the two Bills. The LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2010 sought to enlarge LegCo by adding five geographical constituency seats and creating a new DC Functional Constituency (i.e. the DC (second) FC) of five seats and to make other changes related to LegCo elections.

The Bills Committee held a total of 11 meetings and received views from 78 organizations and individuals. The Bills Committee reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 18 February 2011. The Chief Executive Election (Amendment) Bill 2010 and the Legislative Council (Amendment) Bill 2010 were introduced into LegCo on 10 December 2010. The House Committee agreed to form a Bills Committee to study the two Bills. The CE Election (Amendment) Bill 2010 sought to increase the number of seats for each EC sector to 300, allocate the additional seats among the EC subsectors and make changes in relation to DCs and Chinese medicine subsectors and other related matters. The LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2010 sought to enlarge LegCo by adding five geographical constituency seats and creating a new DC Functional Constituency (i.e. the DC (second) FC) of five seats and to make other changes related to LegCo elections.

The Bills Committee held a total of 11 meetings and received views from 78 organizations and individuals. The Bills Committee reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 18 February 2011. The Chief Executive Election (Amendment) Bill 2010 and the Legislative Council (Amendment) Bill 2010 were introduced into LegCo on 10 December 2010. The House Committee agreed to form a Bills Committee to study the two Bills. The CE Election (Amendment) Bill 2010 sought to increase the number of seats for each EC sector to 300, allocate the additional seats among the EC subsectors and make changes in relation to DCs and Chinese medicine subsectors and other related matters. The LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2010 sought to enlarge LegCo by adding five geographical constituency seats and creating a new DC Functional Constituency (i.e. the DC (second) FC) of five seats and to make other changes related to LegCo elections.

The Bills Committee held a total of 11 meetings and received views from 78 organizations and individuals. The Bills Committee reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 18 February 2011. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 2 March 2011. The two bills were passed by LegCo on 3 March and 5 March 2011 respectively. [Meeting schedules] [Report]

The Chief Executive Election (Amendment) Bill 2010 and the Legislative Council (Amendment) Bill 2010 were introduced into LegCo on 10 December 2010. The House Committee agreed to form a Bills Committee to study the two Bills. The CE Election (Amendment) Bill 2010 sought to increase the number of seats for each EC sector to 300, allocate the additional seats among the EC subsectors and make changes in relation to DCs and Chinese medicine subsectors and other related matters. The LegCo (Amendment) Bill 2010 sought to enlarge LegCo by adding five geographical constituency seats and creating a new DC Functional Constituency (i.e. the DC (second) FC) of five seats and to make other changes related to LegCo elections.

The Bills Committee held a total of 11 meetings and received views from 78 organizations and individuals. The Bills Committee reported its deliberations to the House Committee on 18 February 2011. The Bills Committee made a report to the Council on 2 March 2011. The two bills were passed by LegCo on 3 March and 5 March 2011 respectively. [Meeting schedules] [Report]
